creditline: Gift of Edith and Norman Garmezy
description: dark boats on water at center; bridge with arches at right; buildings and large tower at center and left in background
inscription:
Signature and Inscription

LRC, in pencil: no 97
portfolio: From From "L'Estampe originale, Paris," vol. VIII, 1894, f.
provenance: [Hill-Stone, New York]; Edith and Norman Garmezy, Edina, MN; their gift to MIA, 1998
signed: Bottom center, in pencil: Jo Pennell / Del. Sc. Imp.
text: Joseph Pennell evokes complex reactions from connoisseurs of etchings, for he was both a fervent anti-Semite and a master of his craft.  He was largely self taught, but acknowledged that James McNeill Whistler was "the greatest etcher of them all… [he] is and always will be my master." The atmospheric tone and choice of subject of this print owe much to Whistler's influence.
title: The Thames
